J.A.D.E.
JavaTM Addition to Default Environment.

      Just as the constant increase of entropy is the basic law of the universe,
      so it is the basic law of life to be ever more highly structured and to
      struggle against entropy!                    VÃ¡clav Havel

  Here you will find the most comprehensive package for "serious" JavaTM applications:

  • Real-time framework:
    • Objects can be allocated on the "stack" to avoid garbage collection.
    • Faster code executions by reusing stack/pool objects instead of creating new objects.
    • Easier concurrent programming in low level methods with no thread creation overhead.
  • A math package, which includes a first (and I believe unique) generic Matrix class capable to resolve linear system of equations involving any kind of elements (e.g. LargeInteger, Complex, Quantity, Function, Matrix, etc.).
  • Functions package for symbolic calculations and analysis.
  • Units package (e.g. SI units) developped in collaboration with the JSR-108 experts group.
  • Strongly typed quantity classes (in the physics package) with dimension-checking done in the form of class-type checking (e.g. the division of a Length by a Duration returns a Velocity instance).
  • Support for Standard, Relativistic, High-Energy, Quantum and Natural physical models.
  • Support for the encoding of objects into XML; and the complementary reconstruction of the object graph from XML (see xml package).
  • XML parsing with no String allocation! It allows our RealtimeParser to run several times faster than conventional SAX2 parsers.
  • Monetary package fully integrated with units (JSR-108) and physical quantities.
  • Struct and Union JavaTM classes for direct interoperability with C/C++ applications (public domain).
  • Miscellaneous utilities classes (public domain) such as FastMap, FastSet, FastString and TypeFormat.

This library is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL).

JADE Version 6.0.0

     

Runtime Environment: J2SE 1.4+ (J2SE 1.3+ for the real-time package alone)

Compilers: JavaTM, JikesTM or GNU Compiler for Java (GCJ)

Build tool: Apache Ant

Collaborative Tool: java.net (code development, comments, issues, bug reporting).

Coding Standard: Addendum to SunTM Code Convention.

Preferred Environment: Eclipse (UTF-8 Encoding).

Benchmark Results: Benchmark (Windows 2000, Compaq at 2.26GHz) (benchmark code in class com.dautelle.JADE).

History

  • Coming soon:
    • Article to be published in Java Developer Journal: "Turbo Charging Java for Real-Time Applications" (overview of JADE real-time framework)
    • Article to be published in Dr Dobbs Journal: "Java for Real-Time, Closing the gap with C/C++" (white paper on different techniques allowing Java to be used in place of C/C++ for safety critical and real-time systems, it includes the stack allocation approach that JADE supports).
    • Complete the work on numerics: LargeInteger, Rational and Real numbers.
    • Add IntervalFunction to allow functions to be defined by intervals.

  • March 24, 2004: JADE 6.0.0
    • Function and Polynomial classes for symbolic functions manipulations.
    • Real-time compliants iterators for FastMap and FastSet (allocatable on the stack).
    • JADE's units package selected as the new baseline for the JSR-108 reference implementation.
    • O'Reilly article on the Java's units specification and JADE ("Apples and Oranges").

  • December 16, 2003: JADE 5.3.9
    • Fixed conversion errors in Non-SI units (ref. java.net issue).
    • Optimized Matrix's inverse.
    • Support for references (C/C++ pointers) and Enum in the Struct class.
    • FastMap, a Map collection with real-time behavior. Unless the map's size exceeds its current capacity, no dynamic memory allocation is ever performed and response time is extremely fast and consistent (up to 5x faster than java.util.HashMap).

  • October 20, 2003: JADE 5.2.5
    • Improved support for multi-dimensional Functions.
    • Initial capacity property for our RealtimeParser. See Parse and CDATA discussion.
    • Struct and Union base classes analogous to C/C++ struct & union (same storage layout, alignment rules, bit-field support, etc.)

  • August 27, 2003: JADE 5.1.1
    • Real-time facility has been re-engineered (see above). The new version allows for low-level concurrent programming. For example, it is now relatively easy to write a concurrent quick-sort twice faster on a pentium with hyper-threading technology (hyper-threading doubles the number of executing threads per processor).

  • July 20, 2003: JADE 4.6.10
    • Faster algorithms (based upon LU decomposition) for our generic Matrix class.
    • Member of java.net.
    • UTF-8 encoding for JADE source code (default encoding on Linux).
    • Real-time XML parser, extremely fast (faster than any conventional SAX2 parser) and small (15Kbytes compressed). It has the unique characteristic of not allocating dynamic memory and still maintains a very small memory footprint (e.g. less than 16Kbytes while parsing 32Mbytes files). Typical applications include SOAP messaging, embedded/realtime systems, web servers (possibly thousands instances running concurrently), etc.
    • Our XML serialization/deserialization facility is now using the new RealtimeParser (300% improvement in deserialization speed).

  • April 27, 2003: JADE 4.4.5
    • Utility class (public domain) TypeFormat to parse text into primitive types (fast and unlike the standard library, does not create temporary objects).
    • StringRT is fully integrated with the new (1.4) java.lang.CharSequence interface (allows for search, concatenation and comparison with any CharSequence such as itself, java.lang.String or java.lang.StringBuffer).

  • March 25, 2003: JADE 4.3
    • Updated real-time FAQ.
    • New class StringRT. This class provides an immutable String several order of magnitude faster than java.lang.String. Concatenation for example, executing in the default JVM heap context (where immutability is guaranteed) is basically as fast as if StringBuffer were being used! For even greater performance, you may execute within a real-time context, then StringRT is 2x-3x time faster than java.lang.StringBuffer (see Benchmark).
    • math package has been extended with generic functions. The combination of discrete functions and physical quantities allows for the numerical resolution of any real-life system (differential). Furthermore, because quantity calculations take into account numeric errors, the solution obtained can be guaranteed (interval solution always contains the exact "theorical" solution)!

  • February 24, 2003: JADE 4.2
    • Monetary quantities have been added to the money package.
    • The physics package has been re-written to support multiple physical models (Standard, Relativistic, HighEnergy, Quantum and Natural).
    • The xml package documentation has been improved.

  • November 24, 2002: JADE 3.1

    The real-time package has been finalized. This framework was initially intended for real-time systems, but its "accelerating" effect might appeal to any system dynamically allocating memory.

    The cost of memory allocations/initialization can be huge (90% of CPU is not rare) and using mutable objects is unsafe... The framework provides "immutable objects" safety and convenience (e.g. no need to specify a "returnValue" parameter) with the performance of "mutable objects".

  • September 4, 2002: JADE 3.0
  • July 28, 2002: JADE 2.0
  • November 12, 2001: JADE 1.4
  • February 24, 2001: JADE 1.3
    Article focusing upon JADE XML support, published in the February issue of Dr Dobbs Journal.
  • December 11, 2000: JADE 1.2
  • December 9, 2000: JADE 1.1
  • September 12, 2000: Official release of JADE 1.0
